message.content: When an object reflects light towards the eye, the light rays enter the eye and stimulate the photoreceptor cells on the retina. This stimulation sends electrical signals to the brain, and as a result, we are able to see the object. Option (B) correctly describes the result of an object reflecting light towards the eye, as we are able to see the object. Option (A) is incorrect because blurring refers to a lack of focus, not the result of reflecting light. Option (C) is incorrect because reflecting light does not cause blindness, although intense glare can temporarily impair vision. Option (D) is incorrect because glare refers to an excessive and uncomfortable brightness, but it is not the result of reflecting light.

This question is asking about the result of an object reflecting light towards the eye. When an object reflects light and that light enters the eye, we can see the object. Option (B) is the correct answer, as it correctly describes the result of the object reflecting light. Option (A) is incorrect because objects that reflect light do not become blurred. Option (C) is incorrect because reflection of light does not cause blindness. Option (D) is incorrect because glare refers to excessive brightness or reflected light that can cause discomfort or difficulty in seeing, but it does not describe the result of an object reflecting light toward the eye.

This question tests our understanding of how reflection works. When an object reflects light towards the eye, it allows the eye to perceive the object and see it. Option (A) is incorrect because while reflection can sometimes cause blurring, it is not the result of the object reflecting light towards the eye. Option (C) is incorrect because reflecting light towards the eye does not cause blindness. Option (D) is also incorrect because glare refers to excessive brightness or harsh light, which may hinder visibility but is not the primary result of an object reflecting light towards the eye.
